awd_titl_txt: Testing eruption-triggering mechanisms at Axial Caldera using statistical data assimilation
awd_abstract_narration:
Millions of people around the world live in the shadows of active volcanic systems. In the United States, active volcanoes in California, the Pacific Northwest, Alaska, and Hawaii are monitored both by ground based instruments and satellite observations to provide early warning of potential eruptions and hazards for local communities. On land, GPS and satellite observations can detect volcano inflation and provide early warning of unrest. However, the link between surface deformation and eruption remains unclear. This project will address this link at the submarine Axial Volcano located on the Juan de Fuca Ridge off of the coast of Oregon. Unlike volcanoes on land, deformation of Axial Volcano appears to be closely linked to eruption. Still, the ultimate eruption triggering mechanism at Axial Volcano remains unknown. Three decades of observations spanning three eruption cycles will provide the data necessary to 'hind-cast' past eruptions at Axial and look for specific eruption precursors in the deformation signal leading up to eruption. Axial Volcano is an ideal natural laboratory to test hypotheses for eruption triggering mechanisms and the link between deformation and eruption at active volcanoes.  This project supports the training of a Ph.D. student.

In this project statistical data assimilation techniques will be used to combine ground deformation observations with finite element models of Axial Volcano to produce hind casts of the 1998, 2011, and 2015 eruptions and investigate what mechanisms might have triggered eruption of Axial. The first step in the investigation will test eruption precursors and triggering mechanism. The second step will develop a method for utilizing data from the Ocean Observatory Initiative Axial Regional Node in near-real time to forecast future unrest at Axial Volcano. These advancements will provide critical insight into the evolution of the Axial volcanic system. Axial Volcano is the only system with a successful deformation based eruption prediction and it could provide an important missing link for understanding how eruptions are triggered at volcanoes.

por.por_cntn:
One of the grand challenges in the field of volcanology is understanding what leads a volcano from a stable state to an eruptive state. It is classically thought that volcanic eruption occurs when the pressure within a magma reservoir reaches a critical point. Since scientists cannot directly observe what is happening in a magma chamber, surface observations such as the swelling of the ground surface is used to provide early warning of unrest and clues about what is happening. However, the link between surface signals and eruption potential remains nebulous. There are many cases of false positives and no definite correlation between the magnitude of surface inflation and eruption potential.

Unlike volcanoes on land, eruptions observed at the submarine volcano Axial Caldera located on the Juan de Fuca Ridge off the coast of Oregon appear to be closely linked to the magnitude of swelling of the ground above. Because of the observed relationship between inflation and eruption, the first successful eruption prediction was made at Axial Caldera based on the inflation signal data alone. Building on the eruption predictable behavior observed at Axial Caldera, this grant supported the development of new numerical models of Axial Caldera to investigate the 1998, 2011, and 2015 eruptions in detail to better understand the mechanisms that triggered eruption of Axial.  

Intellectual Merit

We developed new finite element method (FEM) models to investigate the mechanisms that trigger the eruption of Axial. We found that that pressure within the Axial magma system appears to control the timing of eruption with models predicting eruption when the magma chamber reaches pressures of 12-14 MPa. This finding lends support to the interpretation that eruptions at Axial Seamount are triggered by internal pressurization rather than external forces such as earthquakes (Figure 1; Cabaniss et al., 2020).

Axial Seamount has an extensive network of faults including caldera faults that bound its magma system. Previous numerical models have not taken into consideration how faulting might impact the evolution of the Axial magma system in the lead up to eruption. Although our first suite of models suggest that magma chamber pressure is critical to initiating eruptions, this does not rule out the possibility of faults playing a major role in whether the volcano remains stable or begins to erupt. As such, we developed new numerical models that include regions of weak material to simulate the existence of faults in the system. We find that incorporating fault in our models impacts both the predicted inflation of Axial volcano as well as the timing of its eruption. These findings indicate that a combination of internal magma pressure and external faulting control the behavior of Axial volcano (Figure 2; Cabaniss, 2020).

Using forecasting methods developed for climate and weather forecasting, we tested methods for linking model forecasts with the Ocean Observatory Initiative Axial Caldera Node. We found that the current network of observations limits the ability of statistical forecasting methods to resolve Axial?s magma system evolution. Additional bottom pressure recorders that log the inflation of the volcano are needed for future studies.

Broader Impact

We built a modeling framework for Axial Caldera that combined multiple data sets including: bottom pressure recorders of volcano inflation, seismic tomography data, and earthquake data. These modeling advancements have wide reaching benefits throughout the marine geology and geophysics community as well as in the field of volcanology and hazard assessment. Outcomes from this work have been communicated to the broad community and inspired new directions for other volcanic systems such as Sierra Negra and active volcano in the Galapagos.

The majority of the funding for this work supported former Ph.D. student, Dr. Haley Cabaniss and her career development. Dr. Cabaniss successfully defended her Ph.D. research in 2020 and is currently an Associate Professor at Eastern Kentucky University. Additionally, the outcomes of the research conducted on Axial Caldera were integrated into education modules for courses at the University of Illinois and at Eastern Kentucky University providing students at land-locked institutions the opportunity to benefit from oceanographic data collection and research.

References

  1. Cabaniss et al., Nature Sci. Rep., 2020.
  2. Cabaniss et al., Ph.D. Dissertation - University of Illinois, 2020.
